name: Leinster group
rephrased: A finite group is a Leinster group if its order equals the sum of the orders of its proper normal subgroups.
implication_form: If a finite group has an order equal to the sum of the orders of its proper normal subgroups, then it is a Leinster group.
explained: A Leinster group is a finite group G for which the order of G equals the sum of the orders of all its proper normal subgroups. Formally, if N(G) denotes the set of proper normal subgroups of G (excluding G itself but including the trivial subgroup), then |G| = σ(N(G)), where σ denotes the sum of the orders of the elements in the set.
